processed_hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abdullah ibn al-Aqram al-Khuza'i: I was with my father at al-Qa' from Nimrah when a group of riders passed by us and dismounted by the side of the road. He said to me: O my son, stay with your belongings until I go to these people to ask them. So I went out looking around, and behold! I found the Messenger of Allah ﷺ. I prayed with him, and I was looking at the light patches on the armpits of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ whenever he prostrated.

narrators.name: Abu Bakr ibn Abi Shayba

chainIssues: Chain uses عَنْ twice (Dawud from Abdullah, Abdullah from his father) which creates slight ambiguity, but all narrators are reliable

potential_issues.impact: This is a companion's account, not directly attributed to the Prophet ﷺ. The chain stops at Abdullah ibn al-Aqram al-Khuza'i without explicit connection to the Prophet ﷺ

potential_issues.issue: Use of عَنْ in multiple links
potential_issues.impact: While all narrators are reliable, the use of عَنْ (from) rather than حَدَّثَنَا creates minor ambiguity about directness of transmission, though this is mitigated by the known reliability of Dawud and Abdullah ibn Abdullah

Topics: Description of the Prophet's method for prayer
Incident showing physical characteristics observed during prostration

processed_hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abdullah ibn Jubayr al-Khuza'i: While the Messenger of Allah ﷺ was walking with his companions, a man from his companions took a cloth to shade him. The Prophet ﷺ removed it and said: I am only a human being like you.

Chain uses عَنْ twice (Isra'il from Simak, Simak from Abdullah ibn Jubayr) creating some ambiguity, though all are reliable

potential_issues.impact: This is a companion's account of an incident involving the Prophet ﷺ, but not a direct quotation attributed to the Prophet ﷺ. The incident is narrated from the companion's perspective

processed_hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by the father of Nafi' ibn Khalid al-Khuza'i: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ prayed a light prayer with complete bowing and prostration, and said: This was a prayer of hope and fear. I asked my Lord Mighty and Majestic three things regarding it, and He granted me two and withheld one from me. I asked my Lord that He would not afflict you with a punishment that He inflicted upon those before you, and He granted me that. And I asked Him that He would not place over you an enemy who would ravage your homeland, and He granted me that. And I asked Him that He would not cause you to be divided into sects and make some of you taste the punishment of others, and He withheld that from me. Abu Malik said: So I asked him (Nafi'): Did your father hear this from the Messenger of Allah ﷺ? He said: Yes, my ears heard him narrating to the people that he heard it from the mouth of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ.

narrators.name: Ya'qub ibn Humayd
narrators.full_name: Ya'qub ibn Humayd al-Saksakah al-Marwazi
reliabilityIssues: Saduq with weak memory in some narrations

reliabilityIssues: Some scholars note he had weakness in transmitting from certain teachers

chainIssues: Mawquf: Chain stops at companion level with narration of what the Prophet said rather than direct marfu' attribution
Multiple uses of عَنْ creating mild ambiguity, though all narrators are reliable
Ya'qub ibn Humayd is graded Saduq which is lower than Thiqah - may affect overall reliability

potential_issues.issue: Ya'qub ibn Humayd graded as Saduq (truthful but not high-tier reliable)
potential_issues.impact: First narrator is of lower reliability grade (Saduq) compared to other chains. Saduq narrators are acceptable but can have weak memory in some narrations. This affects the overall strength of the chain
Abu Malik from Nafi', and Nafi' from his father uses عَنْ, creating potential ambiguity about directness, though all are reliable narrators
This is a companion's (or early narrator's) account of what the Prophet ﷺ said and did, mediated through dialogue between Nafi' ibn Khalid and Abu Malik. Not a direct marfu' hadith
The hadith includes a dialogue where Abu Malik questions Nafi' about whether his father heard this directly from the Prophet, adding another layer of narration

Topics: Supplication to Allah for protection from punishment
Protection from external enemies and internal division
Incident showing the Prophet's role as intercessor
Explanation of the Prophet's prayers for his ummah

processed_hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Alqamah: The Prophet ﷺ said to them in the year of Mu'raysee when they embraced Islam: From the completeness of your Islam is that you give Zakat on your property. And he said to them in the year of Mu'raysee: I am sending to you one who will take Zakat on your property.

narrators.name: Ya'qub ibn Humayd
narrators.full_name: Ya'qub ibn Humayd al-Saksakah al-Marwazi

narrators.name: Isa ibn al-Hadram
narrators.full_name: Isa ibn al-Hadram ibn Kulthum ibn Alqamah al-Khuza'i

chainIssues: Chain has Isa ibn al-Hadram (Saduq) and Ya'qub ibn Humayd (Saduq) which weakens reliability
Uses عَنْ in transmission from Kulthum
Marfu' chain with mixed reliability grades

potential_issues.issue: First two narrators are Saduq (truthful but weak memory)
potential_issues.impact: Ya'qub ibn Humayd and Isa ibn al-Hadram are both Saduq grade, which is below Thiqah. This affects the overall reliability of the chain. Saduq narrators are acceptable but less reliable than Thiqah
Chain is attributed to the Prophet ﷺ but relies on intermediate narrators of lower reliability grades

Topics: Incident at Mu'raysee when people accepted Islam
Zakat as part of the completeness of Islam
Sending of Zakat collectors to tribes

processed_hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Alqamah: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ sent al-Walid ibn Uqbah ibn Abi Mu'ayt to take our charity (Zakat). He proceeded until he came near us, and that was after the Battle of Mu'raysee, then he returned. We rode after him and drove a portion of our charities (Zakat) and expenditures which they were carrying. He arrived before them and came to the Prophet ﷺ and said: O Messenger of Allah, I came to a people in their state of ignorance and they were strong in fighting and refused to give the charity. The Prophet ﷺ did not change (his decision) regarding that until the revelation came to him: O you who have believed, if there comes to you a fasiq (immoral person) with information, verify it (Surah al-Hujurat 49:6). And the Mustaliq (tribe) came to the Prophet ﷺ following al-Walid with a portion of their obligatory contributions (Fara'id) which they were driving, and they mentioned that to him and that they went out seeking al-Walid for their charity but did not find him. He said: So they raised to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ what was with them and said: O Messenger of Allah, we received the news of your messenger's departure and we were pleased with that, and we said: We will meet him. But we received news of his return and we feared that might be a displeasure against us. And they offered to the Prophet ﷺ that he buy from them what remained. So he accepted from them the obligatory portions (Fara'id) and said: Return with your expenditures, for we do not sell anything from the charity until we take possession of it. So they returned to their families, and he sent to them one who took the rest of their charity.

narrators.name: Ya'qub ibn Humayd
narrators.full_name: Ya'qub ibn Humayd al-Saksakah al-Marwazi

chainIssues: Chain has two Saduq narrators (Ya'qub and Isa) at the beginning
Uses عَنْ from Kulthum creating some ambiguity
Long complex narration with embedded dialogue
Marfu' hadith despite being mediated through multiple Saduq narrators

potential_issues.issue: Two Saduq grade narrators at the beginning of chain
potential_issues.impact: Ya'qub ibn Humayd and Isa ibn al-Hadram are both Saduq (truthful but weak memory). This is a significant weakness. Saduq narrators are acceptable for Hasan grade but represent lower reliability
The hadith contains a complex story with multiple sub-narratives and dialogue, which increases the risk of transmission errors
This hadith provides the historical context for the revelation of Surah al-Hujurat 49:6. While this is historically significant, it adds complexity to the chain

Topics: Incident of Walid ibn Uqbah and the Mustaliq tribe's charity
Context of revelation of Surah al-Hujurat verse 6
Handling of charity by the Prophet ﷺ
Moral character of some companions under scrutiny

processed_hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Nafi' ibn al-Harith: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: From the happiness of a person is the good riding animal, the righteous neighbor, and the spacious dwelling.

narrators.name: Abu Bakr ibn Abi Shayba
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Ibrahim ibn Uthman ibn Khawwastu al-Abadi

narrators.name: Waki'
narrators.full_name: Waki' ibn al-Jarrah ibn Malih al-Kufi

narrators.name: Sufyan
narrators.full_name: Sufyan ibn Sa'id ibn Masruq al-Thawri

narrators.name: Habib ibn Abi Thabit
narrators.full_name: Habib ibn Abi Thabit Samarah ibn Sharik al-Kufi

narrators.name: Khumayyl
narrators.full_name: Khumayyl (first name uncertain)

narrators.name: Nafi' ibn al-Harith
narrators.full_name: Nafi' ibn al-Harith ibn Kaladah al-Thaqafi

chainIssues: Habib ibn Abi Thabit is a mudallis (category 2) using عَنْ, though generally acceptable
The chain appears to have a joint transmission where Khumayyl narrates directly from Nafi', which is unusual but possible

potential_issues.issue: Habib ibn Abi Thabit is mudallis (category 2)
potential_issues.impact: Habib is known to do tadlis, but he is classified as category 2 mudallis, which generally does not significantly affect reliability when using عَنْ. Since Sufyan al-Thawri (a reliable narrator) is transmitting from him, this is acceptable
The presence of Khumayyl with direct narration (حَدَّثَنِي) suggests this may be an alternative transmission path within the same chain

Topics: Description of the good in worldly matters
Aspects of happiness: good riding, righteous neighbor, spacious dwelling
